Detailed Description

Class Date

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

__construct ( )

CONSTRUCTOR 4 optional ways of how this can be handled No arguments: in this case, the Date instance corresponds to the current local date and time One argument, of type INT: The argument is interpreted as a local timestamp in seconds One argument, of type STRING: the argument is interpreted as a local date and time in RFC-1123 format Two-to-Six arguments, all of type INT: handled similarly to the parse() method, above

dateConvert (   $storedTime,
  $storedZone,
  $userZone,
  $format 
)

Converts a date from one timezone to another. Generally for changing from one stored date (as UTC) to the user's timezone

Parameters
string $storedTime the stored time
string $storedZone the timezone that the time was stored in
string $userZone the timezone to convert the time to
string $format format (for use in date() ) for the date
Returns
string

getSeconds ( )

returns seconds (0-59)

Returns

getTime ( )

returns a complete date as elapsed seconds since the Unix epoch (midnight January 1, 1970 UTC) note that this is not actually ECMA-compliant since it returns seconds and not milliseconds

Returns
int
getTimeOffset ( )

returns difference between local time and UTC as measured in minutes (east of Greenwich = positive, west of Greenwich = negative)

Returns
int
getTimezoneOpts ( )

creates an array of timezone options, each are pipe delimited for use in gForm option sets

Returns
array
getUTCDate ( )

the UTC-specific get*() methods below are defined in much the same way except we use gmdate() instead of date(). returns day of month (1-31)

Returns
int

toLocaleString ( )

returns the date formatted according to local conventions and using local time

Returns
bool|string
toString ( )

return an implementation-dependent string representation of the local date and time that is human-readable but DOES NOT use locale-specific formatting. Return as mysql-style DATETIME format

Returns
mixed
toUTCString ( )

returns RFC-formatted date (see toGMTString()

Returns
string
static UTC (   $year,
  $month,
  $day 
)
static

Returns the UTC timestamp in seconds for a local date and time passed to it as a set of three (required) to six (possible total) arguments in the following order: $year: a 4-digit year $month: the number of the month (January=0, December=11) $day: the day of the month (1-31) $hours: Hours (0-23) $minutes: Minutes (0-59) $seconds: Seconds (0-59)

Parameters
$year
$month
$day
Returns
int
static UTC2MySQLDateTime ( )
static

returns current UTC timestamp date in MySQL datetime format

Returns
string
utime ( )

generates time of day to millisecond precision

Returns
int
valueOf ( )

this is an alias for getTime() once again ECMA specifies milliseconds rather than seconds as it's implemented here

Returns
int
